title: 111_s3167
content: The Act titled "Census Oversight Efficiency and Management Reform Act of 2010" outlines the authority and duties of the Director and Deputy Director of the Census. The "Census Oversight Efficiency and Management Reform Act of 2010" amends Section 21 of the title 13, United States Code, defining the roles of the Director and Deputy Director of the Census. The Director is appointed by the President with Senate approval, and must have demonstrated ability. The Director of the Census must have demonstrated ability in managing large organizations and experience in statistical data analysis. The Director reports directly to the Secretary of Commerce and is independent from other government officials. No officer or agency can require the Director to submit legislative recommendations or testimony for review. The Director of the Census must have experience in managing large organizations and statistical data analysis. They report to the Secretary of Commerce and are independent from other government officials. The Director is not required to submit legislative recommendations or testimony for review before Congress, with a 5-year term limit in office. The Director of the Census is appointed for a 5-year term and can serve until reappointed or until a successor is appointed, but not longer than 1 year after the end of the term. The President can remove the Director from office with written communication to Congress. The Director is responsible for all powers and duties of the Bureau, with authority over personnel and activities. The Director of the Census has the authority to establish, alter, consolidate, or discontinue organizational units within the Bureau as necessary. The Director can also establish advisory committees to provide advice on any function. Members of advisory committees may receive compensation and expenses. The Director of the Census can establish advisory committees without compensation but with transportation expenses and per diem. A technology advisory committee must be established within 180 days, with members selected from public, private, and academic sectors. The technology advisory committee, comprised of members from public, private, and academic sectors, will recommend and publish reports on using commercially available technologies to enhance efficiencies and manage costs in census implementation. The Director may establish regulations in consultation with the Secretary. The Director has the authority to assign duties, delegate tasks, and authorize redelegations to officers and employees of the Bureau as necessary. All official acts and decisions made by these individuals will have the same effect as if done by the Director. Any assignments or delegations must be published in the Federal Register before taking effect. The Director of the Bureau may utilize personnel from other federal agencies, including the Armed Forces, with consent. They can also accept voluntary services. Additionally, there is a Deputy Director of the Census appointed within the Bureau. The Deputy Director of the Census, a career reserved position, appointed by the Director, shall perform designated functions. Transition rules apply for the initial appointment of the Bureau of the Census Director. The Deputy Director of the Census, a career reserved position, appointed by the Director, shall perform designated functions. Transition rules apply for the initial appointment of the Bureau of the Census Director. Code, as amended by subsection (a), outlines the interim role of the current director of the census after the date of enactment. The officer serving as Director of the Census on December 31, 2011, shall assume the powers and duties of the Director until the initial Director takes office and report directly to the Secretary of Commerce. A clerical amendment is made to the item relating to section 21 in the table of sections for chapter 1 of title 13, United States Code. The Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with the Director of the Census, is required to submit draft legislation to Congress by January 1, 2011, containing technical amendments to title 13, United States Code, to implement the purposes of the Act. Additionally, there is a provision for an Internet response option. The Director of the Census will provide a plan to Congress within 180 days on implementing an Internet response option for the 2020 Census and American Community Survey. The plan will detail feasibility testing, stakeholder consultation, data collection, and data protection. Annual reports will also be required. The Director of the Census will submit annual reports to Congress on the status of the next decennial census, starting with the 2020 census. The reports will include performance goals, risks, and mitigation plans for each significant operation. The Director of the Census will submit annual reports to Congress on the status of the next decennial census, including detailed milestone estimates, updated cost estimates, and descriptions of contracts over $50,000,000 for each significant operation. The term 'significant decennial operation' includes programs related to address list development, data processing, hiring temporary employees, marketing, and coverage measurement. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 1 of title 13, United States Code. The amendments made by this section apply to budget requests for fiscal years starting after September 30, 2010. Passed the Senate on December 8, 2010. AN ACT to amend title 13 of the United States Code for a 5-year term for the Director of the Census and define the authority and duties of the Director and Deputy Director of the Census.
